title: Simple `for` statement can be broken with linker error since nightly-2021-06-10-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu

labels.name: A-linkage
labels.description: Area: linking into static, shared libraries and binaries

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

Minimal reproducible code:

`.cargo/config.toml`

```toml
[build]
target = "x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu"

[profile.release]
panic = "abort"

[profile.dev]
panic = "abort"

[target.x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu]
linker = "rust-lld"

rustflags = [
  "-C", "no-redzone=yes",
  "-C", "relocation-model=static",
  "-C", "link-arg=--entry=KernelMain",
  "-C", "link-arg=--image-base=0x100000",
]
```

`main.rs`

```rust
#![no_std]
#![no_main]
#![feature(asm)]

use core::panic::PanicInfo;

fn halt() -> ! {
    loop {
      unsafe {
        asm!("hlt");
      }
    }
  }  

#[panic_handler]
fn panic_handler(_: &PanicInfo) -> ! {
    halt()
}


#[no_mangle]
pub extern "C" fn KernelMain(){
    for i in 0..1{

    }
}
```

This linker error is not observed when I use `nightly-2021-06-09-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu` or comment out the empty `for` statement in KernelMain. This issue was reproduced in the other environment also by my friend.

I assume #86003 is related to this problem but I'm not so much sure why these change can cause this problem. I would happy to provide further more investigation if it was needed.
